02-06-2009, 12:11 PM #1 katland View Profile View Forum Posts View Blog Entries View Articles Registered User Join Date Oct 2006 Posts 16,913 assistance programs - heating costs, phone bill, food, etc. I thought I'd start this thread, in light of all the grim economic news. If anyone has info on additional programs, please share! Thanks.
LIHEAP - credit towards your heating costs An insert in my electric&gas bill said that income limits have been raised, I don't know if this happened in all states. http://liheap.ncat.org/sp.htm click on your state to see state&fed programs available in your area
Lifeline / Linked In - credit towards your phone bill http://www.lifeline.gov/lifeline_Consumers.html
Angel Food Ministries food program (buy box(es) of food at less than retail) http://angelfoodministries.com/
food stamp program http://www.fns.usda.gov/fsp/
food banks by state http://www.wadv.org/food.htm
Links for each state for the SHARE food program are on page 3 of this post: http://www.freesamplesite.com/ydf/sh....php?p=1514722
Modest Needs - they seem to help with needs-based requests http://www.modestneeds.org/ Reply With Quote 02-06-2009, 07:21 PM #2 katland View Profile View Forum Posts View Blog Entries View Articles Registered User Join Date Oct 2006 Posts 16,913 http://www.aoa.org/visionusa.xml
VISION USA provides basic eye health and vision care services free of charge to uninsured, low-income people and their families. VISION USA was established in 1991 by AOA doctors of optometry who donate their services.
Eligibility Requirements VISION USA is open to children and adults. General eligibility requirements vary by state. To receive free services, you must: Have a job or live in a household where there is one working member Have no vision insurance (this may include Medicare/Medicaid) Have income below an established level based on household size Not have had an eye exam within two years Reply With Quote 02-06-2009, 08:45 PM #3 Breezin View Profile View Forum Posts View Blog Entries View Articles Registered User Join Date Mar 2002 Location I am the 53% Posts 6,887 In all honesty I am not 100% familiar with this program
http://www.citizensenergy.com/englis...OilHeatProgram
available in NY,NJ, NH, MA, VT,CT, DE, DC, RI, MD, PA, ME, VA, MI, WI, IN, AK
I believe it gives you up to 100 gals of free heating oil Reply With Quote 02-07-2009, 10:02 AM #4 Kolbycheese View Profile View Forum Posts View Blog Entries View Articles Registered User Join Date Aug 2007 Posts 250 Dial 211 from any landline in any state. They are great! Helped us find food banks, pay electric bills and utility bills and also paid some of our rent when we were down on our luck. You have to wait on hold for a while, but they are really an awesome group. They can also help with free dr. visits and pregnancy problems or birth control. HTH Reply With Quote 03-17-2009, 05:33 AM #5 txlady9 View Profile View Forum Posts View Blog Entries View Articles Registered User Join Date Dec 2006 Posts 563 :) Originally Posted by katland http://www.aoa.org/visionusa.xml
VISION USA provides basic eye health and vision care services free of charge to uninsured, low-income people and their families. VISION USA was established in 1991 by AOA doctors of optometry who donate their services.
Eligibility Requirements VISION USA is open to children and adults. General eligibility requirements vary by state. To receive free services, you must: Have a job or live in a household where there is one working member Have no vision insurance (this may include Medicare/Medicaid) Have income below an established level based on household size Not have had an eye exam within two years Wow I can't believe it, I wasn't sure if this was real, but I went ahead and applied and guess what?? I got a certificate in the mail with the name of an eye doctor, I have to set up an appointment!! This is so great for me!! Thank you OP. I will let you know how it goes. Reply With Quote 03-26-2009, 09:54 AM #6 katland View Profile View Forum Posts View Blog Entries View Articles Registered User Join Date Oct 2006 Posts 16,913 I'm not familiar with this organization, but it's listed on NJ's dept of labor assistance site.
http://www.uneedpsi.org/CMS400Min/index.aspx Patient Services Inc. A non-profit premium&co-payment assistance foundation for the chronically ill. How We Help
PSI evaluates an individual's financial, medical, and insurance situation to determine who is eligible for premium or co-payment assistance. We provide help for many illnesses and offer many types of assistance.
If you would like more information about the help available from PSI for the treatment of any of the listed diseases in this section, please call 800.366.7741. Our client service representatives can begin your application right over the phone as well as mail you the appropriate form. I got a certificate in the mail with the name of an eye doctor, I have to set up an appointment!! This is so great for me!! Thank you OP. I will let you know how it goes. I just got home from the eye doctor, they did cover the cost of my eye exam and I am happy. Didn't cover glasses, but that's ok, I saved a bit and I really needed an eye exam and I qualified. Reply With Quote 04-27-2009, 02:05 AM #8 HUERTA53 View Profile View Forum Posts View Blog Entries View Articles Registered User Join Date Apr 2004 Location Austin, Tx Posts 3,287 Thanks for the eye wear info as I need new glasses so hope I get in too. Reply With Quote 04-30-2009, 05:35 PM #9 aqualina56 View Profile View Forum Posts View Blog Entries View Articles Registered User Join Date May 2008 Location PA Posts 365 Does anyone know of any programs for low income dental help? I don't qualify for assistance because I'm alittle above poverty level but I desperately need to have some work done because of bad infection in my mouth that is affecting my health. I can not afford to get it taken care of and medical insurance I have (Medicare plan Today's Option due to disability) won't cover it because it is considered dental work. Anyone know of anywhere that might be able to help? I live in PA. Not sure if they have any available programs or not. Thank you in advance. Reply With Quote 04-30-2009, 05:51 PM #10 katland View Profile View Forum Posts View Blog Entries View Articles Registered User Join Date Oct 2006 Posts 16,913 I posted some info here on dental programs that may help you http://www.freesamplesite.com/ydf/sh...ghlight=dental
You can double-check whether you qualify for assistance here http://www.dpw.state.pa.us/ServicesP.../003671559.htm
Also, check any dental schools you live near, they usually offer low-cost or sliding-fee services Univ of Penn (they have a clinic as well as a community outreach program) http://www.dental.upenn.edu/patients/index.html Temple U dentistry links page, not sure if they have a clinic http://www.temple.edu/dentistry/links.htm Univ of Pittsburgh (school-based clinic) http://www.dental.pitt.edu/patients/index.php
Depending on where you live, you might be near one in a neighboring state, check the American Dental Asso's website listing of dental schools http://www.ada.org/prof/ed/programs/..._ddsdmd_us.asp
If none of that helps, try googling low-cost dental care in PA, something like that.
HTH
Edited to add: also call your local hospital(s), especially ones in an urban or low-income area. The ADA's site shows only 1 dental school in NJ, but I know of 2 large hospitals that also have dental clinics. Last edited by katland; 04-30-2009 at 05:53 PM . Reply With Quote
